title: A Hazard Based Approach to User Return Time Prediction

author: Komal Kapoor, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, University of Minnesota

segmentation: Hey, good morning everyone.
This is Comal Anne.
I'm going to talk about a hazard based approach to return time prediction.
This is a collaborative work.
I want to acknowledge my coauthors, my professor Jerry Provosty were from Minnesota and my coworkers at Pandora Towen mention so.
Here's a quick outline of my talk and I'll just.
Quickly jump to motivation.
In the interest of time, so user attention problem, attention has been studied for a long time and it all involves basically understanding what factors.
Business work and do not work for its customers and understanding that allows the business to modify its practices.
Re design and restructure its business so that better suits its users.
It also involves identifying at risk users, these other users which are likely to churn, and once they can be identified, you can selectively target them.
You can provide promotions and marketing efforts.

The reason why most of the standard techniques of churn prediction are not applicable to today's web is that those techniques assume a subscription based model where people have users came a clear signal of termination by baby.
Maybe Unsubscribing or something else.
So they give a clear signal that they are not interested in the service anymore.
But in the web environment where the revenue model is AD supported, people need not formally subscribe to a service.
They may register.
An may come and not at their own will.
In such a scenario.
The service has to handle users which have extremely dynamic behavior.

Also the multitude of services available out there, and the number that keep getting added every single day and the amount of content keeps adding every other day makes the environment extremely competitive.
As result services CS Infinite number of first time users which never come back again and they're called dropouts.
Also user behavior is prone to change multiple times during the course of time.
So think about how many times you have tried.
Disconnect ourselves with social media.

Only to turn again data, so the interest levels of people change quite dynamically with time, so as result services now need to concentrate on explicitly on engagement metrics, which are things like user return rate, which is the fraction of users coming to the service every day and the times they spend when they come to the service.
So in this work we are concentrating on the return rate an.
Proposing an approach which is based on user return time prediction to improve the user return rate to a web service.
So, given the user's Visitation history and the observations of its previous return time, the problem is to understand when the user is going to return next to the service.
So now I'll move on to.
Techniques for this work.
We have used techniques from survival analysis, this branch of statistiques has been used to model the time of occurrences of events for a long time.
Classically, the events that have been modeled included deaths in our biological organisms.
Failure in mechanical systems and so on.
They can be applied to model several events on the web, such as the return of a user, the exit of a user from a session, or click.
In this work, we are focusing on the return event one.
Property of these methods is that which makes it really suitable for this kind of work is that they can handle sensor data.
Your sensor data is those events for which we do not see a return time during the observation period.
So think about users which do not return during the observation period.
Such users cannot be just discarded from your analysis, because if you do so, you would introduce a lot of bias, so they have to be maintained explicit.
They have to be.

Pain in the estimation process and survival analysis methods can easily handle that, and the good thing about these techniques is that they can attribute the user return rate to several user features and also other events which may also be dynamic in nature.
So for example, if you think about effects on return rate based on weekday and we can affect an you to Holidays, you can easily incorporate that into your model.
So the model that we use for our work is called the Cox proportional hazard model.
Here we have the hazard function which measures the instantaneous rate of return of the user given the time Census last visit.
The shape of the value of the header function tells you the actual return rate, while the shape carries information about the dynamics in the return behavior.
For example, if you have an increasing hazard function, that means that the likelihood of the event increases as time elapses.
For example, think about adoption of products, so as the time after the release of the product increases, people are more likely to adopt it as information about the product spreads out.
Similarly, there are events like responses to surveys for which the response rate decreases as time elapses, so people either respond to surveys quite immediately, or they do not do so at all.
This talks about the dynamics of the process itself.
What is interesting is to incorporate user level features and how they impact the dawn event.
So the assumption that the model makes is that the user level features only impact the magnitude of the return event event rate and not the shape of the function.
So based on the values of the of the features associated with the user, the hazard value might increase or decrease but would follow the same shape dynamics overtime.
So here is the form of the of the function that we estimate on the data.
So it has two components.
The first is the baseline hazard function.

We assume that the baseline hazard function, which is shared across the users, has the same shape and it is nonparametric, so we are not fitting any form to this data and that allows us to not to make the least amount of assumptions about user dynamic behavior.
The other component incorporates the effect of covariates on the return rate, so it is product of the value of the covariance and regression coef.
These regression coefficients are particularly interesting because they allow us to assess how much each individual feature impacts the return rate and in what direction.

Both these components, the baseline hazard function and the impact of the covariates are independent of each other and learn separately the details of the estimation process are pretty standard and you can refer to the paper for more details for that.
Now jumping to the data and findings.
We have experimented with two datasets from the music domain.
The 1st is a publicly available last FM data set which had just around 1000 users and the 2nd is a larger property data set which had around 73,000 users.
We did both training and testing analysis and cross validation based on the data set and both our training and test data had a lot of multiple observations per user.
This is those users which return multiple times to the service.
If you.
If you do not re wait these observations, then you would bias your analysis to the most frequent users and we did not want to do that.
So we waited each observation per user so that overall each user has unit weight in the data.
So some of the covariates which we created for a particular applications included those related to the typical Visitation behavior.
This incorporated variables meant to assess how loyal and how frequent the user is to the service.
So, so there were things like active weeks.

So how much weeks he was active in the last month, the density of Visitation, how many times he visited in a week, the visit number and also the time weighted average return time that was seen for him in the past.
The more interesting variables were were those which were related to the satisfaction and engagement with the service.
They included explicit and implicit feedback measures like duration in time they spend on the service, the number of distinct songs they listen to, the number of listing.
Artist, they listen to whether they skipped or not and whether they provide any other form of explicit feedback.
These are only for the music domain, but of course you can modify them to suit your service.
One set of covariates which we have not mentioned here, but which are interesting to incorporate would be dynamic covariates like the time of the day and day of the week and Holidays, and so on.
So this is the shape of the baseline hazard function that we learned across users.
And as we can see, this has a declining shape which corresponds to the property of inertia.

As we discussed before, that the likelihood of return decreases as time spent away from the service increases, and that's an important observation because that implies that we have to be extremely careful about getting users to come back soon.
Otherwise they get lost.
So we evaluated a.
Based on the return time prediction, which is the expected return time given the model and the covariates.
Used weighted root mean squared error to evaluate the performance and compared against some of the state of the art techniques for prediction like neural network support, vector machine and so on.
And what we see is that the model is definitely far better than all the other baselines.
Another thing that model can also predict is the expected return time given the observed length of absence.

So as you enter the user and you see that he is not returned, you can use this extra information about the already observed length of absence to update your prediction and because we saw a lot of inertia in users, the estimate of the return time increases as the time that he spends away from the service increases.
So we use the model to make the prediction of future return time.

And as you can see in this graph, the as we incorporate the length of absence in our prediction, we are able to reduce the error in our prediction considerably and the yellow line is the line corresponding to the hazard model and the other lines correspond to linear regression and decision tree regression which were the 2nd, first and second best methods.
And the model does definitely far better job of incorporating this new feature about the length of absence.
Although the other models also had that feature as a.
One of the features of which they were learned, but they could not incorporate it as well.
We also tried to see how the model performs at the classification task which is classifying users into short time return users and longtime return users.
Again, we saw value in incorporating the length of absence information.
So as we kept.

Observing the length of absence for each user, we were able to classify them better, so the F measure increased and again the yellow line is the hazard model and the other the green line corresponds to neural network.
The blue corresponds to logistic regression.
Uh, so finally.
Inclusion in this work we showed proposed approach for return time prediction which is based which is which we suggest is a good approach for handling retention and web services.
We used a Cox proportional hazard model for that and the reason why we did so wise because it could incorporate dynamic return events.

Anet could incorporate the effects of covariates we were able to improve the performance by explicitly incorporating length of absence information in our model and that led to significant improvement in performance.
And we also saw that we outperformed several of the baselines for return time prediction and both classification, although this was not a classification model.
So that's all from my end.
I'll be happy to receive questions.
